nodes.bodyText: A PSK as used in TLS is always a byte array. In a UI it might be entered as a string but IMHO the parameter type here should be byte[] or the method should at least be overloaded accordingly ...
since this is a new file it should probably be 2020 only, right?
Just copied. We can fix existing code in an additional PR.
empty line between description and params?

nodes.bodyText: The future will fail with the exception thrown by the first failing predicate, but that will not be a ServiceInvocationException. FMPOV you can simply omit the ... with a ServiceInvocationExpception as we do in all the other methods.
nodes.diffHunk:
@@ -318,6 +319,21 @@ private static String registrationWithoutIdUri(final String tenant) { return removeTenant(tenantId, HttpURLConnection.HTTP_NO_CONTENT); } + /** + * Removes configuration information for a tenant. + *

+ * This method simply invokes {@link #removeTenant(String, int)} with {@link HttpURLConnection#HTTP_NO_CONTENT} as + * the expected status code. + * + * @param tenantId The tenant to remove. + * @param ignoreMissing Ignore a missing tenant. + * @return A future indicating the outcome of the operation. The future will succeed if the tenant has been removed. + * Otherwise the future will fail with a {@link org.eclipse.hono.client.ServiceInvocationException}.

nodes.bodyText: what's wrong with the code that already exists and has worked for months?

It assumes that you can delete devices and tenants at the same time. Which you can only, because the current implementations fail to verify the tenant before doing device operations.
Devices and tenants get deleted in parallel. This lead to test failures, when a tenant got deleted before a device. The deletion of a devices would fail, but that would be ignored. Still, the device exists in the data store.
When the next test comes along, creates the same tenant, the device will again be there, and fail the test.
the JavaDoc of the postTest method should be updated accordingly ...
can we use a tenant with a random ID instead?
We could. However, that way I found some other issues. In any case, this is all over the place, and I think it makes sense to do this in another PR, to keep this one smaller.
